à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¥‹ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤—à¥à¤£à¤¸à¤¾à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥ˆà¤•à¤¨à¤¿- à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤£à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¥à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ " à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤ªà¤²à¤¬à¥à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤ªà¤²à¤¬à¥à¤§à¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¤™à¥à¤—à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤° à¤¨à¤¿à¤¯à¤®à¥‹ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ " à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥‡ à¤¹à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥‡’ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µ- à¤—à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥‡ à¤š à¤¦à¥‹à¤· à¤‰à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ " à¤•à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¾ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤‰à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¹à¤¾à¤°à¥‹- à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤¾à¤šà¥à¤š à¥¤ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤¾à¤šà¥à¤š à¤•à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¨ à¤šà¥‡à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤µà¤¿à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤‰à¤ªà¤²à¤¬à¥à¤§à¤¿à¤µà¤¦ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¯à¤®à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¥à¤š à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¤š à¤¤à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‹à¤­à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¥¤ " à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨ à¤à¤µ That the self is eternal and not produced has been proved in Sutra II-3-18. That knowledge is the essential character- istic of the self has been proved in SÅ«tra I1-3-19. That the self is atomic in size has been proved in Sutra II-3-20. The self, who is the knower, has been mentioned by the term knowl- edge; because he has knowledge, as his essential attribute and because also he has to be defined and investigated by the means of the attribute, knowledge. This has been stated in Sutras 11-3-29 & 30. In the SÅ«tra II 3-32 are stated the defects that arise in the schools that accept knowledge as the self, that accept the knowledge produced by other means as the self and that accept the self as being present everywhere. That the self is the doer of good and bad works and not Prakrti has been stated in SÅ«tras II-3-33 to 39. 1 à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥‡ A. 1. à¥§à¥ª à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¤¾à¤°: [à¤…à¤§à¤¿. à¤¶à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤­à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¸à¥ à¤•à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥; à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥‡à¤°à¤•à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤•à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¾à¤§à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤‚ à¤«à¤²à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤­à¤µà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¤™à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿ à¤š à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ â€œà¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤šà¥à¤›à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤ªà¥‡à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤µà¥ˆà¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ " à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨ à¤à¤µ à¤•à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¤¹à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ " à¤…à¤‚à¤¶à¥‹ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤¾à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¤šà¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¦à¤¾à¤¶ à¤•à¤¿à¤¤à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¤§à¥€à¤¯à¤¤ à¤à¤•à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤…à¤ªà¤¿ à¤š à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤¨à¥ˆà¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤°à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¥¤ " à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿, “à¤…à¤¨à¥€à¤¶à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¶à¥‹à¤šà¤¤à¤¿ à¤®à¥à¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤œà¥à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤‚ à¤¯à¤¦à¤¾ à¤ªà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥€à¤¶à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤®à¤¹à¤¿à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¥€à¤¤à¤¶à¥‹à¤•à¤ƒ " " à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤‚ à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤‚ à¤¤à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤ˆà¤¶à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ Suppose the Praká¹›ti is the doer, then this Praká¹›ti happens to remain common to all the individual selves. As such, all the individual selves must enjoy the fruits thereof. In Sutras II-3-40 & 41, it is stated that the effert of the self has the approval of the Highest Person. The inherent property and the natural state of the self has been stated to be many. They are-(a) dependent on Karman, (b) subject to affliction, (c) not all knowing, (d ) his Mukti (or final liberation) is dependant upon the means of worship. That of the Brahman is stated to be (a ) not tainted with faults, (b) all knowing, (c) Possessed of true will, (d) lord of all beings, The authorities are: 1. à¥® Brahma-Sutras II-3-42 to 46. 2. The Purusa i.e. the individual self sits immersed in grief, and being ignorant and powerless, he feels sorry; when he sees another, the Lord, well worshipped, then he being relieved from grief, attains His greatness’ (S’ve. IV-7). C 3. The destructible is the AvidyÄ or Karman and the immortal is the Vidya or knowledge and He (the Brahman) who commands them is distinct’ (S’ve. 5. 1). à¥¨] à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥§à¥« à¤¸à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ " " à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¤¾ à¤¸à¤‚à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤µà¤•à¥à¤¤à¥‹ à¤¨ à¤¬à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤•à¤¿à¤‚à¤šà¤¨ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤®à¥ " " à¤¤à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤ªà¤²à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¤¶à¥à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤šà¤¾à¤•à¤¶à¥€à¤¤à¤¿ " à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤œà¥à¤à¥Œ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤µà¤œà¤¾à¤µà¥€à¤¶à¤¨à¥€à¤¶à¥Œ " " à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¥à¤—à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥‡à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤°à¤‚ à¤š à¤®à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤œà¥à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µ- à¤®à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ " " à¤¯à¤¦à¤¾ à¤ªà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤°à¥à¤•à¥à¤®à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£ à¤•à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤°à¤®à¥€à¤¶à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¯à¥‹à¤¨à¤¿à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¤¾ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤£à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¾à¤ªà¥‡ à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¥‚à¤¯ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥à¤ªà¥ˆà¤¤à¤¿ " " à¤¸ à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤ªà¥‹ à¤¨ à¤šà¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤•à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¿à¤œà¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾ à¤¨ à¤šà¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤ªà¤ƒ " " à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤œà¥à¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤‚à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥” à¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¥ˆà¤µ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¥€ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¬à¤²à¤•à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤¾ 4. Being embraced by the Intelligent Self, he knows neither the external thing nor the internal thing.’ (Br IV-3-21). 5. ‘One of them eats the sweet Pippala fruit, while the other shines in splendour withou teating at all’ (Mund. III-1-1). 6. ’ The two unborn, the Intelligent and the non- intelligent are the lord and non-lord’ (S’ve. I-9). 4 7. By knowing the individual self and the Impeller to be different, he, being blessed by Him attains immortality’ (S’ve. I-6). 8. ’ When the seer beholds Him, the golden-coloured, the creator, the Lord, the Person and the cause of the Matter, then the wise not tainted with evils, becomes entirely equal to Him, having discarded Punya and Papa (i.e. the effects of good and bad deeds)’ (Mund. III-1-3). 9. ‘He is the cause. He is the Lord of the lord of the senses (ie. the individual self). He has neither generator nor master’ (S’ve. VI-9). 10. He who understands all and knows all’ (Mund. I-1-9). à¥® 11. His supreme power is proclaimed, indeed, as varied and natural and consisting of activity provoked by knowledge and strength’ (S’ve. VI-8). à¥§à¥¬ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¤¾à¤°: [à¤…à¤§à¤¿. "" à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤•à¤²à¤‚ à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤•à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¤µà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¤à¥à¤œà¤¨à¤®à¥ " " à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ ’ 1 à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¨à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥‡à¤•à¥‹ à¤¬à¤¹à¥‚à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¯à¥‹ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥" à¥¤ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¬à¤¹à¥‚à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¯ à¤à¤•à¥‹ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤•à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ " à¤ªà¤¤à¤¿à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µ- à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤°à¤®à¥" à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤—à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤µà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤¶à¥‹à¤šà¤¿ - [à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨à¤¾ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤œà¥à¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨à¥‹à¤ªà¤¾à¤¸à¤¨à¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¤ à¤®à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¤µà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤œà¥à¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤‚à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤°à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¤ à¤•à¤²à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤£à¤—à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¨à¤¾ à¤š à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¸à¥à¤µà¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ª- à¤¶à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥‡à¤µ " à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¸à¤¿ " à¤…à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤® " " à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤¸à¥Œ à¤¸à¥‹à¤½à¤¹à¤‚, à¤…à¤¥ à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¤à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤ªà¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤¸à¤¾à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤¹à¤®- à¤½à¤¹à¤‚ à¤¸à¥‹à¤½à¤¸à¥Œ " à¤®à¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¨ à¤¸ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦ " " à¤…à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¨à¥‹ à¤¹à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤·: + à¤†à¤¤à¥à¤®à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µà¥‹à¤ªà¤¾à¤¸à¥€à¤¤ " " à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤® à¤¦à¤¾à¤¶à¤¾ " 12. ’ He is without parts, without action, tranquil and vithout defect, without taint’ (S’ve. VI-19). 13. He, who is the Eternal among the eternals, the ntelligent among the intelligents, fulfils the desires of many, >eing Himself only one’ (S’ve. VI-13). 14. He is the Lord of the entire world, and the master if one’s Self ’ (MahÄ. NÄr. I-3). The Brahman pervades all the individual souls. There- É”re He is mentioned as one with them. The authorities are:- ( 1 ) ’ That thou art ’ (ChÄnd. VI- 8-7 ) . ( 2 ) ’ This self is the Brahman’ (Br. VI-4-5). (3) Therefore whatever that (deity) is, that am I and vhatever I am, that is that (deity)’ (Ait. Ar. [-4-10). 4 (5) This (the Jiva) is imperfect + should worship Him (the Brahman) as his self’ (Br. I-4-7). 1 ’ à¤…à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤›à¤¿à¤µà¤¾ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤‚ à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤®à¥à¤ªà¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯à¥‡, à¥¨] à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥§à¥­ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤® à¤¦à¤¾à¤¸à¤¾ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¥‡ à¤•à¤¿à¤¤à¤µà¤¾ : " à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤¾à¤šà¥à¤šà¥‹- à¤­à¤¯à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¥‹à¤§à¥‡à¤¨ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤‚à¤¶à¥‹ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤­à¥à¤¯à¥à¤ªà¤—à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¨ à¤•à¥‡à¤µà¤²à¤‚ à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤®à¤¿à¤¦à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤šà¤¾à¤‚à¤¶à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¤ƒ - " à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¥‹à¤½à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ " à¤®à¤®à¥ˆà¤µà¤¾à¤‚à¤¶à¥‹ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤²à¥‹à¤•à¥‡ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¤¨à¤ƒ" à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¥¤ à¤…à¤‚à¤¶à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥ˆà¤•à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤•à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤­à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥‡à¤•à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¥‹ ’ à¤¨ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¶à¤™à¥à¤•à¤¯ " à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤¨à¥ˆà¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¤ƒ" à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤¹à¤°à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¯- à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤£à¤¤à¥ˆà¤•à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤—à¥à¤£à¤¶à¤°à¥€à¤° à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤—à¥à¤£à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤—à¥à¤£à¤¶à¤°à¥€à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤‚à¤¶à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ à¤à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤—à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¶à¤°à¥€à¤°à¤•à¤‚ ( 6 ) ‘The Brahman are the fishermen, the Brahman are the slaves, the Brahman are these gamblers’ (BrahmasÅ«kta). Therefore, it is to be granted that the self is a portion of the Brahman, so that the two statements mentioned above will not contradict each other. This is not established by reasoning alone. The fact that the individual souls are part of the Brahman has been proved by the following scriptural texts and Smá¹›ti passages :- 1. His one fourth part constitutes all the worlds ’ (Puru. Su. 3-22). C 2. In the word of life, the eternal soul is indeed a portion of mine’ (Bha. Gi. XV-8). The objection-a portion of an object means a part of a single unit. Therefore logically there is no possibility of any distinction between these two-is set aside in SuÅ«tra 11. 3. 45. The luminosity, the species, the attribute and the body belong to the fire, the substance, the attributed thing and the soul which are distinct from them. Yet they form a ‘portion of the fire etc. In this way the individual souls 1 à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¥‹à¤§à¥‹ A 2, M 1. à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¥‹à¤§: à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ M 2, 3. 3à¥§à¥® à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¤¾à¤°: [à¤…à¤§à¤¿. à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤—à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¥‹à¤½à¤‚à¤¶à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤à¤µà¤®à¤‚à¤¶à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤­à¤¾à¤µà¥‹à¤½à¤¶à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¥‹ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤ƒ, à¤¨à¥ˆà¤µà¤®à¤‚à¤¶à¥€ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾; à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤° à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤£à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¸à¥à¤µà¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤à¤µà¤‚ à¤š " à¤•à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¾ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ â€ â€œ à¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤šà¥à¤›à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤šà¥à¤›à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤ƒ " à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤š à¤¨ à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¥à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¤¶à¤°à¥€à¤°à¤µà¤œà¥à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤‚à¤¶à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¤¶à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤°à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤à¤•à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤œà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤°à¤¿à¤£à¥€ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¥¤ "" à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤£à¤ƒ à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¥à¥‡à¤¯à¤®à¤–à¤¿à¤²à¤‚ à¤œà¤—à¤¤à¥ à¥¥ â€œ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤¿à¤šà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥ƒà¤œà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤µà¥ˆ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤œ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥ƒà¤œà¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤‚à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¥Œ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤µà¥ˆ à¤¹à¤°à¥‡à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤ƒ " à¥¥ " à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥‹à¤°à¤‚à¤¶à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤µà¤¾à¤ƒ || â€ à¥¤ become a portion of the Brahman, who has them as His body. The individual souls which are portions of the Brahman, have their own inherent characteristics; but the Brahman, of whom the individuals souls are portions, does not possess those characteristics because the things and their attributes are always found to be distinct from each other in regard to their natural state and inherent characteristics. Thus no contradiction arises in what is stated in Sutras II-3-33 and 40. That the individual souls are portions of the Brahman in the same way as luminosity, etc. is stated by Parasara and others- ( 1 ) ’ The fire remains in one place; but its light spreads all round. In this way, all the worlds are the manifestations of the power of the Brahman’ (VisÅ†u I - 22-56). (2) ’ Oh! twice-born one, which ever is created for its generation by an agent, it forms the body of Hari’ (Visnu 1 - 22-38). à¥® (3) All these are produced from a portion of Visnu who appears as all beings’ (Visnu 1-22-20). à¥¨] à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥§à¥¯ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¤ªà¤¾à¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤ªà¤¾à¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤•à¥‹à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤¯à¤£à¥‡à¤¨ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤—à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¥‹à¤½à¤‚à¤¶à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤£ à¤à¤µ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¨à¤¿à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤¦à¥‹à¤·à¤¾ à¤­à¤µà¥‡à¤¯à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ " à¤†à¤­à¤¾à¤¸à¤¾ à¤à¤µ à¤š " à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¨à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¦à¤¾ à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¶à¤°à¥€à¤°à¤•à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤® à¥¤ à¤•à¤¦à¤¾- à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¶à¤°à¥€à¤°à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤¾à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥ ; à¤•à¤¦à¤¾à¤šà¤¿à¤šà¥à¤š à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤•à¥à¤¤- à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¶à¤°à¥€à¤°à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤® à¥¤ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¦à¤¾ à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¶à¤°à¥€à¤°à¤•à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤£à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤¶à¤°à¥€à¤°à¤­à¥‚à¤¤ à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤¨à¤¾à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤¨- à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤—à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤†à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤® à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¦à¤¾ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤ à¤¨à¤¿à¤–à¤¿à¤²à¤¦à¥‹à¤·à¤—à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤µà¤§à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¤¯à¤¾- à¤¸à¤‚à¤–à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¯à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥‹à¤¦à¤¾à¤°à¤—à¥à¤£à¤¸à¤¾à¤—à¤°à¤®à¤µà¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¥ˆà¤µ à¤œà¤—à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¤- Otherwise, if it is viewed that the individual souls become a portion of the Brahman due to a certain limiting conditions, that are either of a true or of untrue nature all the faults, intended to be set aside by the Vedanta texts do attach themselves to the Brahman. This has been stated in Sutra II-3-49. and so on. Therefore, the Brahman has always as his body all the sen- tient and non-sentient beings and is the Self of all those beings. The Brahman is in the state of cause at that time, when His body constitutes the sentient and non-sentient beings without distinct names and froms. He is in the state of effect at that time, when His body constitutes the sentient and non-sentient beings with distinct names and forms. Though the sentient and the non-sentient beings are the body of the Brahman ; yet the sentient and the non-sentient beings, who form the body of the Brahman, do undergo changes and are the seat of the evils. Even then, the Brahman who is the Self of these objects, is the ocean of auspicious qualities, such as knowledge, bliss, etc. which are innumerable, unsurpassable à¥¨à¥¦ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¤¾à¤°: [à¤…à¤§à¤¿. à¤®à¥à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ " à¤¯à¤¤à¥‹ à¤µà¤¾ à¤‡à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ " à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿ à¤µà¤¾à¤•à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤œà¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¯à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¥ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ " à¤¸à¤¦à¥‡à¤µ à¤¸à¥‹à¤®à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¦à¤®à¤—à¥à¤° à¤†à¤¸à¥€à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤à¤•à¤®à¥‡à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤®à¥ + à¤¤à¤¦à¥ˆà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¤ à¥¤ à¤¬à¤¹à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤œà¤¾à¤¯à¥‡à¤¯ " à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤šà¤¾à¤¯à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥:- -— à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾ à¤¶à¤°à¥€à¤°à¤®à¥ " " à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤‚ à¤¶à¤°à¥€à¤°à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¥à¤¿à¤µà¥€ à¤¶à¤°à¥€à¤°à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¶à¤°à¥€à¤°à¤®à¥ à¤à¤· à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾ - à¤ªà¤¹à¤¤à¤ªà¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤®à¤¾ à¤¦à¤¿à¤µà¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤¦à¤¿à¤µà¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤¦à¥‡à¤µ à¤à¤•à¥‹ à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤£à¤ƒ " à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤°à¥à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤£à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¦à¤¾ à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¶à¤°à¥€à¤°à¤•à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤®à¤¿à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¥‚à¤² à¤šà¤¿à¤¦ à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¶à¤°à¥€à¤°à¤•à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤•à¥à¤¤- in excellence and opposed to all evils. That Brahman is the efficient cause and the material cause of the world is esta- blished by the text, ‘From whom all these beings are born’ Tait. III-1-1). Thus this has been correctly stated - He is the Brahman, from whom proceed the creation, etc. of this universe. Consider the scriptural text-Existence alone, my dear boy, this word was in the beginning one only, without a second. It thought may I become many and be born’ (Chand. VI- 2-1 ). The meaning of this text is this â€” That Brahman has always all the sentient and the non-sentient beings as the body has been proved by the following scriptural texts- ( 1 ) ’ He, whose body is the self’ (MÄdh. BrÄhmana). (2) ‘He, whose body is the indestructible one, He, whose body is the earth, He, whose hody is the Avyakta, He is the inner Self of all beings; He is devoid of sins, He is the Divine Lord, He is the One NÄrÄyaá¹‡a’ (Sub. VII - 1). Now the Existence, that has the sentient and non-sentient beings in a gross form as Its body, manifested Itself as having à¥¨] à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¨à¥§ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤®à¥ à¤…à¤—à¥à¤°à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤²à¤¯à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¥‡ à¤¸à¥‚à¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¦à¤¶à¤¾à¤ªà¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¶à¤°à¥€à¤°à¤•à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¥‚à¤ª- à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤¾à¤¨à¤°à¥à¤¹à¤®à¥‡à¤•à¤®à¥‡à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¥€à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤® à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤œà¥à¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¨à¤¿à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¤ªà¥‡à¤•à¥à¤·- à¤®à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤‚ à¤šà¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ " à¤¤à¤¦à¥ˆà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¤ à¤¬à¤¹à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤œà¤¾à¤¯à¥‡à¤¯ " à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤¾à¤¨à¤°à¥à¤¹- à¥¤ à¤¸à¥‚à¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤®à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¶à¤°à¥€à¤°à¤•à¤¤à¤¯à¥ˆà¤•à¤®à¥‡à¤µà¤¾à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¥‚à¤²à¤¦à¤¶à¤¾à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¬à¤¹à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¤ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤œà¤¾à¤¯à¥‡à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¿à¤¸à¤®à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¿à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¤šà¤¿à¤¤à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤š à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤²à¤¯à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¹à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¤°à¥à¤¹à¤¸à¥‚à¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤®à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¥ˆà¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿- à¤­à¤¿à¤°à¤­à¥à¤¯à¥à¤ªà¤—à¤¤à¤ƒ, à¤…à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤­à¥‡à¤¦à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤šà¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¥à¤ªà¤—à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¥¤ a distinct name and form. It in the beginning i.e. at the time of the deluge, remained only one having as Its body all the sentient and non-sentient beings in a subtle form, and did not manifest Itself as having a distinct name and form. The Brahman Himself who is omniscient and omnipotent, remained without a second, not requiring any other efficient cause. The meaning of the scriptural text, ‘It thought-May I become many and be born’ (ChÄnd. VI- 2-1 ) is this - The Brahman remained only one having as His body, all the sentient and non-sentient beings, that had neither name nor form in their subtle state. It thought of becoming many by assuming a gross form, that has a distinct name and form. The words, ’ May become ’ and ’ Be born indicate respectively the distributive and aggregate forms of creation. All VedÄntins accept this doctrine viz-At the time of deluge, the intelligent and the non-intelligent beings do assume a subtle and indes- cribable difference from the Highest Person. Other Vedantins also accept the difference between them produced by ignorance. or limiting conditions as beginningless. Here the peculiarity is this: In the other schools the Brahman becomes ignorant and is associated with limiting conditions. This is opposed à¥¨à¥¨ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¤¾à¤°: [à¤…à¤§à¤¿. à¤‡à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤· : — à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¥ˆà¤µà¤¾à¤œà¥à¤à¤®à¥à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤¸à¤‚à¤¬à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤‚ à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¥‹- à¤§à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¥‹à¤§à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤•à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¥ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤®à¥ à¥© à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¯à¥‹à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¥ à¥© à¥¥ à¤à¤µà¤‚ à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¶à¤°à¥€à¤°à¤•à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤£ à¤à¤µ à¤œà¤—à¤¦à¥à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¨à¤¿à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤š à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤—à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤•à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¤•à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ " à¤¯à¤¤à¥‹ à¤µà¤¾ à¤‡à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ " à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿ à¤µà¤¾à¤•à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¨à¤¿à¤–à¤¿à¤²à¤œà¤—à¤¦à¥‡à¤•à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤® à¤¬à¥‹à¤§à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤®à¥ à¥¥ to what is stated in all scriptural and Smrti texts and reasoning. There will be no such opposition in our school, as all these (i.e. ignorance and limiting conditions) are not recognised. S’ASTRAYONITVADHIKARANA 3 3. Sastrayonitvat. (That the Brahman is the cause of the creation. etc. follows altogether from the scripture), because the scripture alone forms the source (of the knowledge related to Him). The Brahman, who has as His body all the sentient and non-sentient beings, is the material cause and also the efficient cause of the Universe. This fact could not be apprehended by reasoning; but could be proved by scriptures. alone. Therefore it is established that the scriptural text â€¢ From whom, all these things are born (Tait. III. 1) discerns the Brahman, who is the only cause of all the worlds.à¥©, à¥ª] à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¨à¥© à¤¸à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤®à¥ à¥ª à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¥ à¥ª à¥¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤µ- à¤¸à¤¾à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤® à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤šà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤­à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¥‡à¤£ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‡à¤£ à¤—à¥à¤£à¥ˆ- à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤­à¥‚à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¤¨à¤µà¤§à¤¿à¤•à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤­à¤¿à¤§à¥‡à¤¯- à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤£à¤ƒ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¤•à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥à¤ªà¤ªà¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¤à¤° à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¤µà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¤ˆà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤®à¥ à¥« 1 à¤¨à¤¿à¤–à¤¿à¤²à¤œà¤—à¤¦à¥‡à¤•à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤® à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤•- à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤•à¤¦à¥ˆà¤µ à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¨à¤œà¤—à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤µà¥‹à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¤œà¤—à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤•à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤š à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿- SAMANVAYADHIKARANA 4 4. Tattu samanvayat. That (viz. the fact that the scriptures form alto- gether the source of the knowledge relating to the Brahman) results, however, from (His constituting) the true purport (of the scripture ). His constituting the true purport of the scripture is the same as His being the object of human pursuit. Though the function of the proof, known as scripture, ends in determining the object of human pursuit ; Yet the Brahman, who is experi- enced equally by Himself and others in His natural state, in His peculiar characteristics and in His great splendour, is of unsurpassed bliss and this is intended to be denoted by the S’astra. Therefore it is quite right that Brahman could be proved by the S’astra. Thus there is no any defect. Ä°Ká¹¢ATYADHIKARANA 5 It has been previously stated that the Vedantas establish the Brahman, as the sole cause of the entire universe. He à¥¨à¥ª à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¤¾à¤°: [à¤…à¤§à¤¿. à¤—à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤•à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¤•à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤šà¤¾à¤¨à¤µà¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤°à¥€à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤‚ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¥‡à¤£ à¤œà¤—à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤°à¥à¤¹à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤œà¥à¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¤‚à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤‚ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¾- à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¸à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¤ à¤¦à¥‹à¤·à¤—à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤®à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥‹à¤¦à¤¾à¤°à¤—à¥à¤£à¤¸à¤¾à¤—à¤°à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¥ˆà¤µ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦- à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤°à¥à¤¹à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¹– à¤ˆà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥« à¥¥ alone is the efficient cause of the entire universe. time He is in the form of the universe, as He is its material cause also. This fact has to be determined by the Sastras only as the inferential reasoning is incapable of proving it. He is the highest object of human pursuit; because His essential characteristic constitutes the unsurpassable bliss. Therefore the Vedantas surely teach about Him. This fact has been firmly established before. Then in the rest of this PÄda it is stated that as the Prakrti and the individual selves are not fit to be mentioned as the cause of the world. The Vedantas teach about the Brahman only, who is omniscient, who possesses a true will, who is hostile to all evils such as ignorance etc. and who is the ocean of innumerable noble qualities. Of these, the author first states that the Praká¹›ti could not be mentioned in the Vedanta as the cause of the world. 5. Iksaternasabdam. Because the predicative root, Iks is used (in connection with the activity of what constitutes the cause of the world) that which is not in the scope of the scripture alone (viz. the Pradhana or PrakrtÄ±,) is not (referred to in the scriptural passage relating to the cause of the world). ;] à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¨à¥« à¤…à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤®à¥ à¤†à¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿à¤•à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¨ à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤•à¥à¤¤: ? à¤ˆà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¤à¥‡à¤ƒ à¥¤ " à¤¸à¤¦à¥‡à¤µ à¤¸à¥‹à¤®à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¦à¤®à¤—à¥à¤° à¤†à¤¸à¥€à¤¦à¥‡à¤•à¤®à¥‡à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤®à¥ " à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤ à¤œà¤—à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£- à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¤¾à¤°à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¤¿à¤¨ à¤ˆà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¤à¥‡à¤°à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¥‹à¤ƒ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤µà¤£à¤¾à¤¤à¥ " à¤¤à¤¦à¥ˆà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¤ à¤¬à¤¹à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥" à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¥ "" à¤—à¥Œà¤£à¤–à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¥ à¥¬ à¥¥ à¥¤ ’ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤œ à¤à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¤" à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤¨à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¥€à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¸ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤—à¥Œà¤£à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤à¤µà¤®à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤§à¤¾à¤¨ à¤à¤µà¥‡à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¤à¤¿à¤—à¤£ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¥; à¤¨à¥ˆà¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤ªà¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡, à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥‡ That which is not capable of being revealed by the scripture alone, is meant here by the term Asabdai.e. Anu - mÄnika that which is established by the process of logical inference, i.e. the Pradhana. The meaning is that the Pra- dhÄna, is not apprehended by the Vedanta. Why? Because the root Iks (to see, i.e. to think) is used. That is because the root, Iks is used in the scriptural passage ‘It thought May I become manifold and be born (ChÄnd. VI- 2-3 ) to denote the activity of the universal cause; closely related to what is stated in the text, ‘Existence alone, my dear boy, was in the beginning, one only without a second ’ (ChÄnd. VI- 2-1 ). " 6. GauÅ†ascennatmasabdat. If it be said that it (vis, the root Iks), is used here in a figurative sense, it cannot be so; because there is the word Ätman (mentioned in the context). " In the scriptural statement That fire thought ’ ( Chand. VI-2-3 ) the root Iks is used in conection with the action of the non-intelligent substance also. The root apparently is there used in a figurative sense. Likewise in the case of the Pradhana also, the root Ãks is used in a figurative 4 à¥¨à¥¬ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ [à¤…à¤§à¤¿. à¤¸à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤šà¥à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤¨à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¤¿à¤¨ à¤†à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ “à¤¸ à¤†à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾, à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¸à¤¿ à¤¶à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤•à¥‡à¤¤à¥‹ " à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¹à¥à¤¯à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ / à¤¤à¥‡à¤œà¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤­à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤µà¤ªà¤¿ à¤¨ à¤—à¥Œà¤£à¤®à¥€à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥‡à¤œà¤ƒà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤­à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥ˆà¤°à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤šà¥à¤›à¤°à¥€à¤°à¤•à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¥ˆà¤µà¤¾à¤­à¤¿à¤§à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡, " à¤…à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤¯ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‡ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¤µà¤¾à¤£à¤¿ " à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤•à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¥‡à¤¶à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤µ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¥‹ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤­à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ ‘à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤°à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤¯ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤šà¥à¤š à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤šà¥à¤šà¤¾à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤šà¤¾à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤š à¥¤ à¤¨à¤¿à¤²à¤¯à¤¨à¤‚ à¤šà¤¾à¤¨à¤¿à¤²à¤¯à¤¨à¤‚ à¤š à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤šà¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤š à¥¤ à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤šà¤¾à¤¨à¥ƒà¤¤à¤‚ à¤š à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¥â€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤¨à¤®à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤¨à¤‚ à¤š à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¥à¤™à¥ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¦à¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤¯à¤®à¤¨à¥- sense. This is not intelligible; because in the context of the import of the word Sat, the word Atman denoting the intelligent one is used. In the subsequent portion there is the passage-‘He is the Self.’ That thou art, Oh! ’ S’vetaketu’ (ChÄnd. VI-8-7). In fact as regards fire etc. also the power of seeing is not to be explained in a figurative sense, because the words fire etc. denote the Brahman only who has them as His body. All these objects are distinguishable as having a name and form; because the Brahman has entered them, through the individual souls which constitute His body. It is because there is the statement, ‘Indeed entering in the form of the individual self, I evolve the differentiation of names and forms’ (ChÄnd. VI-3-2). The intelligent and the non-intelligent substances are separately stated in the text Having created it, He entered the same; Having entered it, He became Sat and Tyat ( intelligent and non-intelligent ), describable and not describ- able, the support and supported, the animate and inanimate, the truth and untruth. Yet he remained truth’ (Tait. II-6). Having entered the both, He became that and that i.e. He 4 a] à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¨à¥­ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤­à¤µà¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤°à¤£à¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤®- à¤­à¤¿à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤®à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‹à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¥ à¥­ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤‚’ à¤¸à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤­à¤¿à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤œà¤—à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤®à¥, à¤¸à¤šà¥à¤›- à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤­à¤¿à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤®à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‹à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤¦à¥‡à¤µ à¤šà¤¿à¤°à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¨ à¤µà¤¿à¤®à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤½à¤¥ à¤¸à¤‚à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‡ " à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤®à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤· à¤‰à¤ªà¤¦à¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤§à¤¾à¤¨- à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤®à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤·à¥‹ à¤¨à¤¾à¤­à¤¿à¤®à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¥ became the meaning of the words denoting that and that. Thus the fact has been clearly stated in the same context. 7. Tannisthasya moksopadesat. Because it is taught that he, who is firmly devoted to that (viz. the Sat) obtains final release. By the following reason also, the cause of the world. mentioned by the term Sat is other than the Pradhana or Prakyti. It is taught in the context that he, who is firmly devoted to the Truth meant by the term Sat obtains final release. It is taught in the scriptural text, ‘For him so long there is delay, as long as he is not freed from the body; then he will reach the Brahman. (ChÄnd. VI- 14-2) that he, who is firmly devoted to Him, obtains final release. Consider the school that accepts Pradhana to be the cause of the creation etc. of the world. Even they belonging to that school do not accept the fact,-that he, who is firmly devoted to PradhÄna, obtains final release. 1 à¤…à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤‚ A 1, M 2, M 4. à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¨à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ M 1, 2. 8 à¤¨à¤¾à¤­à¤¿à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤: M 1, 2.à¥¨à¥® à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¤¾à¤°: à¤¹à¥‡à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¤¾à¤šà¥à¤š à¥¥ à¥® à¥¥ [à¤…à¤§à¤¿. à¤¯à¤¦à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¿à¤¤à¤‚, à¤¤à¤¦à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¹à¥‡à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥’ à¤…à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥à¤šà¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤ à¥¤ à¤¨ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤®à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¸à¤¾à¤§à¤¨à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‹à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ " à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¸à¤¿ à¤¶à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤•à¥‡à¤¤à¥‹ " à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¨à¤¾ à¥¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¥‹à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¥ à¥¯ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¨ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¥, à¤à¤•à¤µà¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¥‹à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤¨à¤¾à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤¨à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ â€œ à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤‚ 8. HeyatvÄvacanÄcca. Because also it is not declared that it (viz. what is denoted by the word sat or existence) deserves to be discarded. If the Pradhana were meant as the cause of the creation etc. then it would have been taught that what is denoted by the word Sat or existence deserves to be discarded. This has not been done. In the passage ‘That thou art, Oh! S’vetaketu (ChÄnd. VI- 8- 7 ) it is stated that he should be firmly devoted to that viz., Sat, as the means of final release. 9. Pratijnavirodhat. Because also there would then be the contradiction of the proposition (enunciated in the context). From the following reason also the PradhÄna is not the cause of the creation etc; because it contradicts the proposition of cognition of all things from the cognition of a single thing. From the scriptural text, From which the " à¤¹à¥‡à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ M 2, 4. à¥«] à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥©à¥¯ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿” à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¨à¤¾ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥‡ à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¥à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡, à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥‡ à¤šà¤¿à¤¦- à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¶à¤°à¥€à¤°à¤•à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¥ˆà¤µ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®- à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨ à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¤à¤¤à¥‹à¤ªà¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¥ à¥§à¥¦ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¨ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¥ à¥¤ " à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤®à¥‡ à¤¸à¥‹à¤®à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¿à¤œà¤¾à¤¨à¥€à¤¹à¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥ˆ - unheard becomes heard, etc.’ (ChÄnd. VI-1-3 ) arises the proposition that the knowledge of that entity, which is denoted by the word Sat, produces the knowledge of all the sentient and non-sentient beings as they are its effect. Then there is contradiction in the school that accepts the Pradhana as the cause of the world; because Pradhana cannot produce the sentient being. Consider the school that accepts Brahman, who is different from the Pradhana, to be the cause of the world. Then the Brahman, having as his body all the sentient and non-sentient beings, with distinct names and forms is the effect and without distinct names and forms is the cause. Hence it is correct to say that by the knowledge of the Brahman the knowledge of everything is produced. 10. Svapyayat. Because also, there is (mentioned in the context ). the withdrawal (of the individual soul) into its own Selt. By the following reason also the Pradhana is not the cause of the creation etc. of the world. The scriptural passage- Know from me, my dear boy, what deep sleep 6 1 à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¾à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ A 1, M 4. à¥©à¥¦ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¤¾à¤°à¤ƒ [ à¤…à¤§à¤¿. à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¨à¤¾à¤® à¤¸à¤¤à¤¾ à¤¸à¥‹à¤®à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤¦à¤¾ à¤¸à¤‚à¤ªà¤¨à¥à¤¨à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤®à¤ªà¥€à¤¤à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤šà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥€à¤¤à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿" à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤·à¥à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤¤à¤¾ à¤¸à¤‚à¤ªà¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤¯à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¥à¤¯- à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤®à¤ªà¥€à¤¤à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿; à¤†à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¥‹à¤½à¤ªà¥€à¤¤à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¶à¤°à¥€à¤°à¤•à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¥ˆà¤µ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤­à¤¿à¤§à¥€à¤¯à¤¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤œà¥à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤­à¤¿à¤§à¥‡à¤¯à¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¥ˆà¤µ à¤¸à¥à¤·à¥à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤²à¤¯à¤•à¤¾à¤² à¤‡à¤µ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤µà¤™à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤•à¥‡à¤µà¤²à¤¸à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤­à¤¿à¤§à¥‡à¤¯à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ ‘à¤¸à¤¤à¤¾ à¤¸à¥‹à¤®à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤¦à¤¾ à¤¸à¤‚à¤ªà¤¨à¥à¤¨à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤®à¤ªà¥€à¤¤à¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿’ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ is; when any person is known to be asleep, he is then in union with the Sat. He withdraws into his Self. There- fore they say, he sleeps; because he is absorbed into His Self (ie into the Brahman )’ (ChÄnd. VI- 8-1 ) - declares that the individual self, who is asleep and is in union with the Sat, has withdrawn himself to his Self. Hence it is known that what is denoted by the word Sat, is an object other than the Pradhana. The expression,’ Has withdrawn. himself to his Self’ means becomes merged or absorbed into his Self. It is declared in the scriptural passage relating to the differentiation of names and forms, that the Brahman Himself, who has the intelligent and non-intellegent beings for His body and forms their selves, is denoted by the word self which ordinarily means the individual self. By means of the statement, ‘He is then in union with the Sat; He with- draws into his Self’ (Chand. VI-8-1), it is taught that the Brahman, who is denoted by the word mentioning jiva, is free from any association with names and forms at the time of deep sleep also, as He is at the time of universal 1 à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ omitted A 1. 9] à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥©à¥§ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤°à¤£à¥‡ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤µà¤™à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¨à¥ˆà¤µ à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤µà¤™à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤¤à¥ " à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¤¾ à¤¸à¤‚à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤µà¤•à¥à¤¤à¥‹ à¤¨ à¤¬à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤•à¤¿à¤‚à¤šà¤¨ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤®à¥" à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤† à¤®à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤œà¥à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤µà¤™à¥à¤—à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤µ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¤¯à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥‹à¤¦à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤·à¥à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤¿- à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¥‡ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‡ à¤µà¤¿à¤¹à¤¾à¤¯ à¤¸à¤¤à¤¾ à¤¸à¤‚à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤µà¤•à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤°à¤ªà¤¿ à¤œà¤¾à¤—à¤°à¤¦à¤¶à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤µà¤œà¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‹ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤®à¤­à¤¿à¤§à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¨ à¤•à¤‚à¤šà¤¨ à¤ªà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿, à¤…à¤¥à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¨à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£ à¤à¤µà¥ˆà¤•à¤§à¤¾ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ " à¥¤ dissolution and He is hence to be denoted merely by the word Sat or Existence. 6 To the same effect, it is stated in a similar context elsewhere that, owing to his (i.e. the individual self) not being associated with names and forms, he is embraced by Him who is omniscient; and consequently it is said. that, when he is embraced by the omniscient Self, he does not know anything that is external or internal’ (Brh. IV-3-21). Indeed till his final release the individual. soul is associated with names and forms; and it is, therefore, there is born in him the knowledge of objects other than himself. At the time of deep sleep he certainly gives up names and forms, and is embraced by the Sat (i.e. by the Brahman); and again in waking state, he becomes associated with names and forms and becomes possessed with various names and forms. This is clearly stated in other scriptural passages, namely,’ When he (i.e. the individual self) is deeply asleep, he sees no dreams whatsoever, and he be- comes one wholly with the PrÄna (Brahman ) . ’ (Kaus. II. 30 ) . ‘From that Self, the PrÄá¹‡Äs (i.e. JÄ«vas) proceed towards their own places’ (Kaus. II-34 ). To the same effect is the 1 à¤•à¤¥à¤‚à¤šà¤¨ M 24. à¥©à¥¨ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¤¾à¤°: [ à¤…à¤§à¤¿. (( à¤à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤†à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¤¨à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡" à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ " à¤¤ à¤‡à¤¹ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤˜à¥à¤°à¥‹ à¤µà¤¾ à¤¸à¤¿à¤‚à¤¹à¥‹ à¤µà¤¾ à¤µà¥ƒà¤•à¥‹ à¤µà¤¾ à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤¹à¥‹ à¤µà¤¾ + à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¦à¤¾ à¤­à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ " à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¥ à¤—à¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¥ à¥§à¥§ à¥¥ à¤¸à¤•à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¤¦à¥ à¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¥à¤ªà¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¤¦à¤¿ à¤¨ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ 1 à¤†à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾ à¤µà¤¾ à¤‡à¤¦à¤®à¥‡à¤• à¤à¤µà¤¾à¤—à¥à¤° à¤†à¤¸à¥€à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤¿à¤‚à¤šà¤¨ à¤®à¤¿à¤·à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¸ à¤ˆà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¤ à¤²à¥‹à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¥ à¤¸à¥ƒà¤œà¤¾ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¸ à¤‡à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤²à¥‹à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¤¸à¥ƒà¤œà¤¤ " à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾ (( following scriptural passage also-To whatever state these beings belonged before the deep sleep, namely of a tiger, or a lion, or a wolf, or a boar etc. they come again to that state when they wake ’ ( Chand. VI- 9-3). 11. Gatisamanyat. Because there has to be similarity of import (between the passage under reference and the other passages relating to the case of the creation etc. of the world). There has to be similarity of import among all other Upanishadic passages and the upanishadic passage under reference. Hence it is known that the Pradhana is not the cause of the creation, etc. of the world. In all the scriptural passages stated below, the Lord of all is made out to be the cause of the world- (1 ) ’ The Self, indeed, this one only was in the begin - ning. Nothing else lived. He thought, May I create the worlds. He created these worlds’ (Ait. I - 1 ) . 1 ’ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾à¤¯à¤¥à¤‚ A 1.a] à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ “1 à¥©à¥© à¤à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨ à¤†à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤‚à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸ à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤ªà¥‹ à¤¨ à¤šà¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤•à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤œà¥à¤œà¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾ à¤¨ à¤šà¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤ªà¤ƒ” à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¸à¤•à¤²à¥‹à¤ªà¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤° à¤à¤µ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤œà¤—à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¥à¤š à¥¤à¥¤ à¥§à¥¨ à¥¤ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤ªà¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¤¦à¤¿ â€œ à¤†à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨: ’ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤ƒ + à¤†à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨’ à¤†à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¤ƒ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨ à¤à¤µ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾- à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤œà¥à¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤® à¤à¤µ à¤œà¤—à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¥ "" ( 2 ) ’ From that same Self, the spatial ether came into existence’ (Tait. II-1-1). (3) He is the cause. He is the Lord of the lord of the senses. He has neither progenitor nor superior’ (S’ve. VI-9). 12. Srutatvacca Because also it is revealed (in the very Upanisad in which the passage under discussion occurs, and in other Upanisads, that the Supreme Self is the cause of the universe). Indeed, in this Upanisad ( vic. the ChÄndogya) in the following passages, ‘From the Self the PrÄÅ†a came into existence etc, and from the Self, the spatial ether came into existence (chand. VII-26-1)’ it is stated that all are produced from the Self only. Therefore that the cause of the universe is the Brahman who is all-knowing Highest person and distinct from the inanimate Pradhana, stands firmly. 1 à¤†à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¤à¤¾à¤²à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤° à¤•à¥‹à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤ªà¤¾à¤ à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤®à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤•à¥‹à¤¶à¤ªà¤¾à¤ à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤†à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ 5 à¥©à¥ª à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¤¾à¤°: à¤†à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤®à¤¯à¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤®à¥ à¥¬ à¤†à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤®à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¥ à¥§à¥© à¥¥ [à¤…à¤§à¤¿. à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤—à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤‚à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿, à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤—à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾ à¤¬à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥‹ à¤®à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¨ à¤œà¤—à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤®à¥, à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤à¤¤- à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨ à¤†à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤‚à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤ƒ " à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤°à¤­à¥à¤¯ " à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤° à¤†à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤®à¤¯à¤ƒ " à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤®à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¦à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥‹à¤½à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤®à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤—à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¥‹à¤½à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤œà¥à¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¥ˆà¤µ à¥¤ 1 ANANDAMAYADHIKARANA 6 13. Anandamayobhyasat à¥¤ That, which is denoted by the term Anandamaya ( is the Brahman); because there is (in the context), the repetition of various grades (of bliss which culminate in the Anandamaya or the Highest Bliss). No doubt the individual self, that possesses intelligence and that is different from the Pradhana, has the power of seeing; yet the individual self, neither in the state of bondage nor in the state of final release, can be the cause of the universe. The scriptural text beginning with ‘From the same self, the spatial ether came into existence’ and ending with ‘Different from this VijÃ±Änamaya, is the Inner-Self Ananda- maya (Tait. II-1-1) declares that the Anandamaya men- tioned as the cause of the universe, is the all-knowing Highest 1 à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ A 1, M 2. 4 1 à¤…à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤®à¤¯: M 1, M 2. V1Ã±anamaya is the individual soul whose essential characteristic is knowledge. â€¢ Ä€nandamaya is the Brahman whose essential characteristic is the abundant bliss. à¸¢ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥©à¥« à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ ? à¤…à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¤¾à¤¤à¥ | à¤†à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤®à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¤¯à¤¦à¤¶à¤¾à¤¶à¤¿à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤®à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾- à¤¸à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ " à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¶à¤¤à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤œà¤¾à¤ªà¤¤à¥‡à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸ à¤à¤•à¥‹ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤£ à¤†à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤ƒ " 11 â€œ à¤¯à¤¤à¥‹ à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¥‹ à¤¨à¤¿à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤…à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¯ à¤®à¤¨à¤¸à¤¾ à¤¸à¤¹ à¥¤ à¤†à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤£à¥‹ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¥¤ à¤¨ à¤¬à¤¿à¤­à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¨ " à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¹à¤¿ ‘à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤®à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¤µà¤§à¤¿à¤•à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¤¯à¥‹- à¤½à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤šà¥‡à¤¨à¥à¤¨ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤šà¥à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¥ à¥§à¥ª à¥¥ " à¤¸ à¤µà¤¾ à¤à¤· à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤°à¤¸à¤®à¤¯à¤ƒ " à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¤¯à¤Ÿà¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤°à¤£à¤¾- " Self, who is other than the individual soul. Why? Because of the repetition. Because there is repetition of the bliss in various grades which culminates in the Anandamaya and which (bliss) forms the summits of unsurpassable condition. This Anandamaya of the unsurpassable condition is repeat- edly mentioned in the text, for meditation The hundred- fold of the bliss of Prajapati is equal to the single bliss of the Brahman (Tait. II-8-4), ‘Wherefrom speeches together with the mind return not having reached it. He who knows the. Brahman’s bliss fears not from anything’ (Tait. II-3-8). 14. Vikarasabdanneti cenna pracuryat It may be said that owing to there being the affix (Maya) significant of modification, (the Anandamaya is) not (the Brahman); but it is not (right to say ) so because that (affix Maya) signifies abundance. The affix Mayat means modification in the context ‘That this person is Annarasamaya (i.e. the modification of à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾ A 2, M 1. à¥©à¥¬ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¤¾à¤°: [à¤…à¤§à¤¿. à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤®à¤¯ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤®à¤¯à¥‹. à¤¨à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤šà¥‡à¤¨à¥à¤¨, à¤…à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¥‹à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤šà¥à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥ à¤à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¤‚ à¤®à¤¯à¤¡à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ (C à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨ à¤†à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤‚à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤ƒ " à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿’ à¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤° à¤†à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤°à¤£à¥‡ à¤š à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤®à¤¯ à¤à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ ‘à¤‰à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤šà¥à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤· à¤à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤®à¤¯à¤ƒ || à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤¾à¤šà¥à¤š à¥¥ à¥§à¥« à¥¥ " à¤à¤· à¤¹à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿" à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤œà¥€à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¹à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤®à¤¯à¥‹ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¦à¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¨ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤—à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾ à¥¥ the essence of food)’ (Tait. II-1-3). Therefore, the term Anandamaya also means the modification of bliss. Hence Anandamaya is not the Highest Self, that does not undergo modification. It is not so. Because there is contradiction of the purport, the affix Mayat is understood to mean here ‘abundance’. The scriptural text ‘From that very same Self, the spatial ether came into existence’ (Tait. II-1-1) refers to the Self, that does not undergo modification. The notion that the affix Mayat denotes modification, has been given up already in the case of PrÄá¹‡amaya. Following this argu- ment, it should be accepted that the Anandamaya is only the Highest person; because there is an abundance of bliss in Him. 15. Taddhetuvyapades’acca Because also this Ä€nandamaya is declared (in the contex) to be the cause of that (which forms the bliss of the individual selves). ‘For, He Himself causes the bliss’ (Tait. II-7-1). In this passage it is declared that Anandamaya causes the bliss of
